contentrichtext.text: {{italic title}} {{Taxobox | name = ''Pinus serotina'' | image = Pinus serotina USBG.jpg | image_width = 240px | status = LR/lc | status_system = IUCN2.3 | regnum = [[Plant]]ae | divisio = [[Pinophyta]] | classis = [[Pinophyta|Pinopsida]] | ordo = [[Pinales]] | familia = [[Pinaceae]] | genus = ''[[Pine|Pinus]]'' | subgenus = ''[[Pinus classification|Pinus]]'' | species = '''''P. serotina''''' | binomial = ''Pinus serotina'' | binomial_authority = [[André Michaux|Michx.]] }} '''''Pinus serotina''''' ('''pond pine''', '''marsh pine''', '''pocosin pine''') is a [[tree]] found along the [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]] coastal [[plain]] of the [[Eastern United States|eastern]] [[United States]], from southern [[New Jersey]] south to [[Florida]] and west to southern [[Alabama]]. This [[pine]] often has a crooked growth pattern and an irregular top and attains the height of 15–20 m, occasionally up to 30 m. The needles are in bundles of three or four, and of length 15–20 cm. The almost round cones are 5–9 cm long with small prickles on the scales. Its cones are [[serotinous]] and require fire to open. The pond pine is found in wet habitats near ponds, bays, swamps, and [[pocosin]]s.<ref name="Moore2008">{{cite book |author=Moore, Gerry; Kershner, Bruce; Craig Tufts; Daniel Mathews; Gil Nelson; Spellenberg, Richard; Thieret, John W.; Terry Purinton; Block, Andrew |title=National Wildlife Federation Field Guide to Trees of North America |publisher=Sterling |location=New York |year=2008 |page=73 |isbn=1-4027-3875-7}}</ref> The species name is derived from the persistently unopened cones that may remain closed for several years before they release their seeds; the opening is often in response to forest fires. At the north end of its range, it intergrades and hybridises with [[pitch pine]] (''P. rigida''); it is distinguished from that species by the longer needles and on average slightly larger cones. Some botanists treat pond pine as a subspecies of pitch pine. <gallery> Image:Pinus serotina map.png|Natural range. Image:PondPineCone.wmg.jpg|Pond pine cones are smaller and rounder than [[Loblolly Pine|loblolly pine]] cones. Image:PondPineNeedles.wmg.jpg|Unlike loblolly pines, pond pines have the ability to grow needles directly from the trunk.<ref name=carolinanature>Trees, Shrubs, and Woody Vines of North Carolina: [http://www.carolinanature.com/trees/acfl.html ''Pond Pine (Pinus serotina)'']</ref> </gallery> ==External links== *[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=210001651 Flora of North America, Profile and map: ''P. serotina''] *[http://www.na.fs.fed.us/spfo/pubs/silvics_manual/Volume_1/pinus/serotina.htm USDA FS: Silvics of Trees of North America. ''Pinus serotina'' Michx. Pond Pine] ==References== {{reflist}} * {{IUCN2006|assessors=Conifer Specialist Group|year=1998|id=42414|title=Pinus serotina|downloaded=12 May 2006}} {{Commons}} [[Category:Pinus|serotina]] [[Category:Trees of the Southeastern United States]] [[Category:Trees of Alabama|Pinus serotina]] [[Category:Trees of Florida|Pinus serotina]] [[Category:Trees of Georgia (U.S. state)|Pinus serotina]] [[Category:Trees of Maryland|Pinus serotina]] [[Category:Trees of New Jersey|Pinus serotina]] [[Category:Trees of North Carolina|Pinus serotina]] [[Category:Trees of South Carolina|Pinus serotina]] [[Category:Trees of Virginia|Pinus serotina]] [[Category:Least concern flora of the United States]] [[Category:Trees of Delaware]] [[Category:Trees of the United States]]
